p: Attempts to produce cobalamin supplements from non-animal sources have been made using certain algae (e.g., Chlorella) and cyanobacteria such as Spirulina (Arthrospira), which is known to contain large amounts of vitamin B 12, though unfortunately, it is biologically inactive in humans [ 77, 80, 87]. The same happens with fermented foods (such as tempeh), edible mushrooms and nutritional yeast that cannot be relied upon as adequate or practical sources of the vitamin [ 69, 80].
